#Text=Gabriël Grupello
#Text=Gabriël Grupello

#Text=( also Gabriël de Grupello or Gabriël Reppeli ; 22 May 1644 – 20 June 1730 ) was a Flemish Baroque sculptor who produced religious and mythological sculptures , portraits and public sculptures .
#Text=He was a virtuoso sculptor who enjoyed the patronage of several European rulers .
#Text=Life
#Text=Early life and training
#Text=Grupello was born as the son of Bernardo Rupelli , an Italian cavalry captain in Spanish service , and his Flemish wife Cornelia Delinck . [ 1 ]
#Text=His father , who died at a young age , was a member of the higher non-aristocratic class of society .
#Text=Grupello later styled himself as Chevalier de Grupello , but a noble ancestry has not been demonstrated .
#Text=At age 14 , he started a five-year training as a sculptor in the Antwerp workshop of leading Baroque sculptor Artus Quellinus I .
#Text=He may have assisted Quellinus with the sculptural decorations in the Royal Palace of Amsterdam . [ 2 ]

#Text=He completed a further two years of study in Paris and Versailles , where he was in contact with his compatriots Philippe de Buyster , Gerard van Opstal and Martin Desjardins and learned the technique of bronze casting .
#Text=He subsequently worked for two years for the sculptor Johan Larson in The Hague . [ 1 ]
#Text=In Brussels
#Text=Head of a horse , Schwetzingen Castle
#Text=He returned to Flanders in 1671 and two years later he became a master of the Brussels Guild .
#Text=He opened a workshop in Brussels , which became very successful and employed many assistants .

#Text=He enjoyed the patronage of the city as well as that of various European rulers , including the Spanish king Charles II , William II of Orange and Frederick III , the Elector of Brandenburg . [ 2 ]
#Text=During his time in Brussels , he also fathered a son ( born 1671 ) and a daughter ( born 1674 ) with his mistress Johanna Louisa Quebault ( Tebout ) . [ 1 ]
#Text=In Germany
#Text=In 1695 , the Elector Johann Wilhelm appointed Grupello as his official court sculptor and Grupello then moved to live and work in Düsseldorf .
#Text=He created numerous sculptures of the royal couple in marble and bronze , and was responsible for the supervision of craftsmen who worked on the Elector 's palaces .
#Text=Grupello also designed a fountain known as the Grupello pyramid for the Galerieplatz in Düsseldorf ( now in Mannheim ) .
#Text=Grupello married Anna Maria Dautzenberg , the daughter of the Elector 's lawyer , in 1698 .
#Text=Five children were born from this marriage . [ 1 ]
#Text=The Elector gave Grupello in 1708 a house in the city centre . [ 3 ]
#Text=The house , which is still called the Grupello-Haus or " Grupello House " , is believed to have been designed by the Italian architect Matteo Alberti .

column1: #Text=Grupello carried out an important reconstruction of the building and used the house as the living quarters of his family and partially also as a studio .
#Text=Originally , two busts representing the Greek goddesses Artemis and Aphrodite presumed to be by Grupello were placed above the portal of the house .
#Text=The original bronze statues are now in the local Stadtmuseum Landeshauptstadt Düsseldorf and have been replaced by two concrete cast replicas . [ 4 ]
#Text=With the death of Elector Johann Wilhelm in 1716 , the employment of the sculptor at the court came to an end .
#Text=Elector Johann Wilhelm 's successor Elector Carl Philipp introduced austerity measures and dismissed officials and artists .
#Text=Grupello continued to live in Düsseldorf and in 1619 the Holy Roman Emperor Charles VI appointed him as Imperial sculptor .
#Text=In 1725 , Grupello and his wife moved into the quarters at Ehrenstein Castle in Kerkrade ( now in the Netherlands ) of their daughter , who was married to an imperial official .
#Text=He died there in 1730 at the age of 86years . [ 1 ]
#Text=Work
#Text=Narcissus
#Text=, 1680 – 85 , Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium
#Text=Grupello was a versatile artist in terms of the subject range of his sculptures as well as the materials in which he worked .
#Text=He executed works in marble , ivory and wood and was rare among his contemporary Flemish Baroque sculptors in that he also made bronze statues .
#Text=A prime example is the bronze equestrian statue of the Elector Johann Wilhelm .
#Text=His early work shows a classicist tendency , which may be due to his study period in France .
#Text=In Brussels , his work was influenced by the Flemish Baroque , and in particular Peter Paul Rubens , and developed into a full-blown Baroque style . [ 1 ]
#Text=A major work that Grupello created in this style in Brussels is the marble wall fountain , intended for the main ballroom of the wholesale fishmongers guild .
#Text=It is this Baroque style that he brought to Düsseldorf when he moved there .
#Text=In his later life , he turned more to religious art and produced crucifixes , Madonnas and statues of saints . [ 1 ] [ 2 ]
